speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Caroline, if you've been in therapy for two years and  you're feeling like you're no longer making any progress,  perhaps you've reached a plateau, or you and your therapist  have simply gone as far as you can together.

speaker: Caroline
text: [_v.o_] Maybe it is time for a change.  He's kind of dry and  long-winded.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, two years is certainly a long time to spend with a  psychiatrist you find dry and long-winded.

speaker: Roz
text: A-men to that!

speaker: Caroline
text: Thanks, Dr. Crane.  You've given me a lot to think  about.  Would it be OK if I called back sometime and picked  your brains?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, just consider me your mental banjo.  Well, that's it  for this fine Friday, Seattle.  This is Frasier Crane saying,  "we'll see you next week."

speaker: Roz
text: [_coming into the studio_] Good show, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_exhausted_] Oh, Roz.  I've been waiting for this moment the  entire week. [_slowly takes off his headphones in happiness_]

speaker: Roz
text: That's what I love about you, Frasier.  You work hard and you  play hard.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, you have no idea how much I've been looking forward to  this weekend.  There comes a time when even the most  conscientious of psychiatrists has had his fill of other  people's problems.

speaker: Delivery Boy
text: Hi.  Is one of you Roz Doyle?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes... that's all the clues we're going to give you.  _The delivery boy hands Roz the package, which she signs for and he  leaves._

speaker: Frasier
text: A little offering from one of your suitors perhaps?  A nice  string of pearls?  A teardrop pendant?

speaker: Roz
text: [_opening package and tearfully turning to Frasier_] It's a  brick of cheese!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, on the right chain I can see that looking smart.

speaker: Roz
text: It's from my family.  They're in Wisconsin at my Uncle's  dairy farm having a family reunion.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, why didn't you go, Roz?

speaker: Roz
text: There wasn't time.  But now I wish I'd gone.  Frasier, we  always have so much fun.  Like this one time there was this  huge cheese party and one of my uncles started speaking in  cheese language.  You know, like instead of saying, "Hello,  how are you?" he'd say, "Hello, Havarti."  Someone else would  go "Oh, I'm Gouda."  Oh I don't know, what would come after  that?

speaker: Frasier
text: If I'd been there, the sound of a gunshot!

speaker: Roz
text: [_tearful_] Don't make fun.  I miss those people.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Roz, oh... [_going to console her_] There, there.

speaker: Roz
text: We play games and sing songs.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, of course.  I know.

speaker: Roz
text: And Aunt Libby does cannonballs into the lake.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh yes, the memories must be...

speaker: Roz
text: And Uncle Ned has too much to drink and he starts putting  pants on all the cows!

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen, Roz.  If what you're looking for is family fun  tonight, why don't you come to my place?  It's my Dad's  birthday.  I completely forgot about it last year and I'm  going to make up for it this year.  There's just one rule.  No work, just a good time.

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, I don't think I'd be much fun.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, I insist.  There's no one I enjoy partying with more  than you and I just hate to see you like this.  I Camembert  it!

speaker: Roz
text: [_crying_] Oh.  So sweet.   **WHAT IF HE HAD TAKEN A REALLY BIG BREATH?**    _Scene Two -- Frasier's Apartment  Frasier comes into the apartment with a cake, parcels and food.  Eddie is lying on the couch. Martin and Daphne are nowhere to be  seen._

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, it's someone's birthday!  I hope you're all in the  mood for a party.  I know I am.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_from the kitchen_] YOU'RE BLOODY IMPOSSIBLE!

speaker: Martin
text: [_from the kitchen_] AND YOU'RE A BLOODY NAG!

speaker: Daphne
text: DON'T YOU SHAKE THAT CANE AT ME!

speaker: Martin
text: QUACK QUACK QUACK - hey!  _The cane comes flying out the kitchen followed by Martin.  Daphne storms out after him._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, for heaven's sake, not again!

speaker: Martin
text: Just decided what I want for my birthday: fire Daphne!

speaker: Daphne
text: You'd have to re-hire me first, because I quit!  I hope  I never see this place or that hateful old canker sore  ever again.

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay, what is it this time?

speaker: Daphne
text: The usual.  I ask him to do his exercises and he twists his  face up like a mewling little baby.

speaker: Martin
text: Why don't you tell him how you asked me to do it - by pouring  my beer down the sink and banging on the spaghetti pot with  a wooden spoon?

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm here for your health.  I don't have to be your friend.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, that's good!  Because I've got a friend here [_gestures  to Eddie_] who doesn't happen to be a yammering nag!

speaker: Daphne
text: [_throwing Martin's cane away_] Eddie, fetch.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_catching the cane_] Oh, stop this!  You two are having the  same argument all the time.  You can just pick this up again  tomorrow.  Tonight we are going to have a party.  Dad, I went  down and got your favorite lemon cake.  I also got some snacks  and some champagne.  Can we all just agree to try and have a  little fun this evening? [_The doorbell rings_] Now that is  probably Roz.  She's been very down this week and what she's  in need of is a very happy and carefree environment.  Frankly,  I could use the same thing.  Now can we just agree to maybe a  truce?

speaker: Martin/Daphne
text: [_muttering over each other_] Yeah, well if she keeps her  mouth shut.../If he can keep his big...

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz! [_kisses her hello_]

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, Martin.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey!

speaker: Roz
text: [_holding up a parcel_] Happy Birthday!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, you didn't have to do this. [_looks inside and laughs_] Hey,  thanks, Roz! [_pulls out a six-pack of Ballantines_] I'll have  to model it for you later.

speaker: Daphne
text: He's already modeling the last one someone gave him.

speaker: Martin
text: Quack!

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen, I have a very nice evening planned.  Can we all just  try to be civil?

speaker: Niles
text: [_storming in_] You unprincipled charlatan!  You unconscionable  fraud! [_turning to Martin_] Happy Birthday, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Thanks.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, what are you talking about?

speaker: Niles
text: You spoke to a patient of mine today, Caroline.  As a result  of your fast-food approach to psychiatry, she left me!

speaker: Frasier
text: Caroline was your patient?

speaker: Niles
text: Two years of my hard work wiped out by one of your two-  minute McSessions.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I merely suggested that she consider a change.

speaker: Niles
text: Based on what diagnostic method?  One potato, two potato?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, fancy that.  A member of the Crane family who doesn't take  the time to do something.

speaker: Martin
text: Quack!

speaker: Niles
text: Exactly, Dad. [_at Frasier_] Quack.

speaker: Martin
text: [_pointing his cane in Daphne's direction_] I was talking to  her.

speaker: Niles
text: Don't you raise your cane at her!    _An unholy rabble begins with everyone arguing and trying to talk  over one another.  Roz decides she's had enough and tiptoes away to  the front door which Frasier suddenly notices._

speaker: Frasier
text: NO, WAIT!  Roz, where are you going?

speaker: Roz
text: I think I'd better leave.

speaker: Frasier
text: We were just talking.  That wasn't fighting.  We were talking.

speaker: Roz
text: I'd really just rather be by myself.  Thanks, guys.  I had a  wonderful time.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_shutting the door behind Roz_] Well, I hope you're happy.  You've ruined her evening.

speaker: Martin
text: Her evening?  It's my birthday.

speaker: Daphne
text: Right.  Well, let's get that underway right now.  Who's ready  for cake?

speaker: Martin
text: I certainly don't want to keep anybody here a second longer  than they have to be so let's get this over with.  Thanks for  a great party!  _Martin blows out his candle and the entire household is plunged into  darkness._

speaker: Niles
text: Well, there's nothing wrong with Dad's lungs.

speaker: Daphne
text: Every light in the city is out.  It must be a blackout.

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't panic.  There's certainly worse places we could all be  in a blackout.

speaker: Niles
text: Like the elevator.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_realizes_] Oh my God, Roz!

speaker: Martin
text: Why couldn't it be Daphne? [_there is a crash and a bang_]  STOP DOING THAT!  _END OF ACT ONE    ACT TWO_  **THERE IS NOTHING WRONG WITH YOUR TELEVISION  (IT'S A BLACKOUT)**  _Scene Three -- Frasier's Apartment  The apartment is still in darkness.  All that can be heard are voices.  _

speaker: Daphne
text: We just need to get some light in here.

speaker: Martin
text: Eddie, where are you?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, excuse me, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: Quite all right, Daphne.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Daphne, where are the hurricane lamps?

speaker: Daphne
text: They're in the kitchen.  I'll get them.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right.  Dad, why don't you light a fire?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, excuse me, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: Not your fault, Daphne.

speaker: Martin
text: Eddie!  Where are you, Eddie?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_annoyed_] I've found him!    _Daphne lights a hurricane lamp and some light is restored to the  apartment.  Niles, who has been hovering near her, quickly backs  away._

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, that's better.

speaker: Martin
text: I'm going to go get my radio.  See what the hell's going on.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_struggling up off the floor_] All right.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Roz, Roz!  You're all right.

speaker: Roz
text: I'm fine.  The blackout hit just as the elevator doors opened  on the fourteenth floor.  So I stood in the hallway trying to  decide whether to come back in here with you guys or take my  chances on the pitch-black streets with the muggers and the  weirdos.  So I went down a couple of flights... and then I  changed my mind.  Meanwhile someone's probably looting my  apartment!

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.  I hear there's a thriving black market in badly-  designed Formica coffee tables.

speaker: Roz
text: At least I have my own sense of style.  You won't even buy  a chair unless some fey French aristocrat has sat his fat  satin fanny in it!

speaker: Niles
text: Louis the Fourteenth was not fey!  Everyone wore garters in  the eighteenth century.  _Niles and Roz begin arguing with each other which Frasier is forced  to break up._

speaker: Frasier
text: People... people... [_they keep arguing_] _SILENCE, ENFANTS!!!_  [_they shut up_] Now we can all sit here in the dark and be  miserable or we can try to have some fun.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm going to call Maris.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Niles has voted.  Who votes for fun?

speaker: Roz
text: I'm going to go and get a big glass of wine.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, it looks like the steaks we were going to have are  out.  I better go and see what I can find.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Daphne.  _Niles quickly drops his handkerchief and is bent over to pick it up  when Daphne turns quickly and bangs into him._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, sorry, Dr. Crane

speaker: Niles
text: Excuse me, Daphne.

speaker: Martin
text: [_coming through with the radio to his ear_] The power is out  all over south Seattle.  They're working on it now.

speaker: Niles
text: [_talking on the phone to Maris_] Hello, Maris.  Thank God I got  you.  Listen, darling, there is no need to panic.  The most  important thing is to stay calm... About the blackout.  Maris?  Take off your slumber mask. [_Niles suddenly holds the phone  away from his ear_] Ooh!  No darling, darling, don't panic.  Honey, no, honey, hon, ho- ho- h... [_turns the phone off and  puts it back in his pocket_] She's fine.    _Reset to: Kitchen  Roz is drinking a glass of wine while Daphne pulls ice cream out of the  fridge._

speaker: Daphne
text: Ooh, yum, scrum, pig's bum.  Here's something nice.  Half-  gallon tubs of Cookies & Cream and Vanilla Fudge.

speaker: Roz
text: Mmm, well let's take care of these right away before they  melt.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, there's no need to worry, ladies.  The freezer will keep  them cold for at least 24 hours.

speaker: Daphne/Roz
text: Shut up!

speaker: Martin
text: [_bored_] Well, I don't like to get nostalgic but it was sure  great last year when you forgot my birthday!

speaker: Frasier
text: You know what we need to do?  We need to liven things up a  little bit.  How about a game?  What was that game we played  at the Rambican's when they were costuming the servants for  the living chess match.  It was... er... oh yes, I remember --  "I'm the dullest person."

speaker: Roz
text: At least pick a game someone else has a chance of winning.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that's got things shakin'.  OK, come on, Dad.

speaker: Frasier
text: What the game is -- we all get pennies and we're supposed to  try and get the other person's pennies.

speaker: Martin
text: [_sarcastic_] Please, slow down!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_gathering everyone round the table_] All right now.  If I was  going to go I would say, "I am the dullest person because... I  have never been on a rollercoaster."  All right?  And then all  of you that have been on a rollercoaster would give me a  penny.  Now we all have our pennies.  Who would like to go  first?  Daphne?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_bored_] I can't think of anything.

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course you can.  Just say the first thing that comes into  your mind.  I'm the dullest person because...

speaker: Daphne
text: [_becoming increasingly exasperated_] Oh, I don't know.  Because  I've never made love in a lift or a phone booth or on an  aeroplane or a merry-go-round.

speaker: Frasier
text: OK -- that's good, but strategically speaking that's not the  best way to get our pennies.  You see it should be something  that someone else might have actually... [_Roz throws in a  penny_] ...done.  _Roz throws in three more pennies while everyone around the table just  looks at her in amazement._

speaker: Roz
text: I was in college.  I was trying to find myself.

speaker: Niles
text: All you needed to do was look under the nearest man.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, Dad.  Get our pennies.

speaker: Martin
text: All right.  I'm the dullest person because... I've never been  to France.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_as the others throw pennies in_] Good, Dad.  That's getting  into the spirit of it.  All right, Niles.  What's something  you've never done?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, let's see.  I'm the dullest person because I've never  sabotaged my brother's career.

speaker: Frasier
text: Will you give it a rest!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, your father could show you how to do that.

speaker: Martin
text: Quack Quack!    _Yet another argument breaks out between everyone while Roz sits in  the middle._

speaker: Roz
text: WILL YOU PEOPLE STOP?  You are torturing me.  I could report  you to Amnesty International.

speaker: Martin
text: [_getting up_] That's it, I'm outta here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Dad, Dad.  You haven't even cut your cake yet.  Where are  you going?

speaker: Martin
text: I'm going to sit in the tub with a hairdryer and wait for  the power to come back on.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, this blackout could go on all night.  It's time I braved  the dark streets and got back to my Maris.  I just hope it  isn't like the lightning storm last month.  The only way I  could coax her out from under the bed was by tying a Prozac  to the end of a string!  _FADE TO:    Scene Four -- Frasier's Apartment  Frasier heads out to the balcony to find Roz there.  No one else is to  be seen._

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz.  Like to have a little cake?

speaker: Roz
text: No, thanks.  This reminds me of Wisconsin.  All dark and  deserted.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's on the license plate, isn't it?  Roz -- what's the real  reason you didn't go to your reunion?  You've always made it  before.

speaker: Roz
text: Well... no, no.  You said you didn't want to hear any more  problems today and I don't blame you.

speaker: Frasier
text: I think we have time for one more caller.

speaker: Roz
text: Well... every year I go to my reunion.  My relatives crowd  around me and I answer the same questions.  No, I'm not  married.  No, I don't have any kids.  Yes, I still have that  tattoo.  No, you can't see it.  It would just be so nice if I  could at least say I have a great career.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, you do have a great career.

speaker: Roz
text: Tell that to my relatives.  You know according to them I  spend four hours on the phone every day with a bunch of  losers and wackos, then I turn them over to some tedious  know-it-all who gives them pointless advice. [_Frasier looks  none too amused_] Oh, that's not me talking.  That's my Uncle  Ned.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yes -- the cow haberdasher.  You know, Roz -- ten years ago  KACL didn't have any women producers?  You're a pioneer.  You've won awards.  You help people.

speaker: Roz
text: Sounds right when you say it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Maybe you're just looking for too much from your job.  Start  exploring other areas of your life.  Interests.  Maybe a  serious relationship?

speaker: Roz
text: Maybe you're right.  I mean, how long can I go on chasing  these hunky twenty-five year-olds that are all looks and no  substance?

speaker: Frasier
text: Exactly, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: No, I'm serious.  I'm asking, how long?  Three, four years?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_from the kitchen_] Oh, bloody hell!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_going through to the kitchen_] Daphne?  Are you all right?

speaker: Daphne
text: I've broke your father's souvenir spoon rest from Atlantic  City.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, good.

speaker: Daphne
text: You know -- when I have my own kitchen I'm going to put my  food right on the damn counter.  I've always said as soon as  I've saved two thousand dollars I'll get my own place.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, how much have you saved?

speaker: Daphne
text: Four thousand.  Oh, I know what you're thinking.  What's wrong  with me?  Why do I stay here?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I was just thinking I must be paying you too much.

speaker: Daphne
text: My friends all say you should be on your own.  Have a place.  Have a life.  Why do I stay here?

speaker: Frasier
text: Could it be that, maybe, you like us?  You know my  Grandmother used to have a cat.  A mangy old thing.  Kept  ruining the furniture and stuff.  I asked her why she kept it  and she said that maybe it was because she liked having  another heartbeat around the house.

speaker: Daphne
text: It just makes me feel like I'm not very ambitious.  I could  be working in a hospital or a clinic.

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course you could, Daphne, but maybe that's not what's  important to you right now.  I think you like being part of a  family.  What's wrong with that?

speaker: Daphne
text: Nothing, I suppose.  Although my friends wonder how I can live  with such demanding men?

speaker: Frasier
text: They call me demanding, do they?

speaker: Daphne
text: No.  Actually they call you a pompous ass!

speaker: Frasier
text: And now you've learned that I'm not?

speaker: Daphne
text: No.  I've learned to work around it.

speaker: Martin
text: Excuse me, I'm getting a beer.  And yes, I know it's not good  for me.  And yes, I know it's going to make me fat.  And yes,  I know it'll keep me from doing my exercises.  Do you have  anything to add to that?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes!  Happy Birthday, you old sod!

speaker: Martin
text: They try to confuse you on purpose. [_takes a swig from his  beer before putting it down in disgust_] Room temperature!  Just like merry old England.  Another place that I'll  probably never get to.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, you used to talk about going to Europe when your hip  improves.  Now you're saying you'll never get there?  What's  changed?

speaker: Martin
text: Nothing!  My hip's the same as it was a year ago.  I had it in  my head it would be better by now, but I'm not and I'm  probably never going to be.  Ah, you don't understand.  You're happy just sitting on your can, doing your little  radio show, living inside your head.  But I'm used to  being out there.    _Frasier and Martin walk back through to the living room to find  Eddie standing on the table trying to get off an ice cream tub, that  has got stuck on his face, with his paws._

speaker: Martin
text: Eddie!

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen, Dad.  You can still travel. [_Martin dismisses him_]  You can.  You can't walk around Paris -- you can sit at a nice  cafe and let Paris walk past you.  Maybe buy a glass of wine  for a beautiful Mademoiselle.  Get yourself a nice bottle of  imported beer.

speaker: Martin
text: I only like Ballantines.

speaker: Frasier
text: In Paris, Ballantine's is imported beer.  And you are the  handsome _american_ with the adorable accent.

speaker: Martin
text: [_thinks about it, then smiles_] They like moustaches over there,  don't they?  _Just as Martin is warming to the idea the door bursts open to reveal  Niles, breathless and panting like he's just run a mile._

speaker: Niles
text: Nineteen floors down to my car!  Garage door's electric!  Can't open!  Twenty floors back up!  Lost count!  Bad lady  upstairs!  Big dog!  Need place to die!  _Frasier gets up to help him, while Roz and Daphne are yelling down over  the balcony._

speaker: Roz
text: [_from the balcony_] Same to you, buddy!

speaker: Martin
text: Who are you talking to?

speaker: Roz
text: Some rowdy guys downstairs.  Come on out here, Martin.  I want  you to introduce us.

speaker: Martin
text: [_going outside_] All right.  Keep your pants on.

speaker: Frasier
text: Here, Niles.  Let me take your coat.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, haven't you taken enough from me today?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles.  You're being silly and irrational.

speaker: Niles
text: Sticks and stones.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're acting just like Dad.

speaker: Niles
text: [_furious_] You take that back!

speaker: Frasier
text: You know you're not really mad at me, Niles.  You know I  didn't tell that woman to leave you.  I merely suggested  it as an option.  It was all her choice.  Could it be  that you're really upset just because you couldn't help  that woman?

speaker: Niles
text: You know, I really hate that.  When you take a simple  criticism and you turn it back on me.

speaker: Frasier
text: I think I'm right.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, of course you're right.  Why do you think I hate it?  Do you have any idea what I went through trying to help  that woman?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I think I do.  Niles, you're a perfectionist.  As faults  go that's not such a bad one to have.

speaker: Niles
text: It just would have been nice if I could have been the one to  tell her that it was time to go.  Instead she had to hear it  from some glib, albeit insightful radio pundit!

speaker: Roz
text: [_coming back in with Martin and Daphne_] Those rowdy guys  downstairs invited us to a blackout party.

speaker: Martin
text: They have cold beer.

speaker: Roz
text: And Carlsberg.

speaker: Daphne
text: You know, it's funny.  I was feeling a bit down before but  suddenly I'm in a party mood.

speaker: Frasier
text: What about our party?

speaker: Roz
text: There are people downstairs.

speaker: Martin
text: They have a barbecue.

speaker: Niles
text: Come on, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, no thank you.  I'm not really in the mood anymore.

speaker: Daphne
text: Don't be a party pooper.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, let him be.  He's always been that way.

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me!  Just a second.  I think maybe it's time for  a little lesson about what it's like to live the life of  this particular party pooper.  I spend the whole damn week  ministering to the troubled and the neurotic and the  sometimes just plain goofy.  Then I hang up my earphones  and it doesn't end there.  Out on the street, at the cafe,  even in this building -- more people come up for help, more  problems.  I suppose they just think it's OK, it's what I  do.  But every time I try to help them it costs me a little  piece of myself.  A little bit here, a little bit there, a  little bit here, a little bit there... until I end up  feeling like a zebra carcass on the Serengeti surrounded by  burping vultures!  Well, this happened to be one of those  weeks.  I had my escape planned.  I was going to come home  for an evening of fun with my extended family.  What do I  get?  I get the four of you going at each other like the  Borgias on a bad day!  So I roll up my sleeves, and I tend  to each one of you.  And you all feel better.  And the  minute you get a whiff of mesquite coming from down below,  you are out the door without so much as a "thank you."  Well, thank you for the invitation, but I am, frankly, fed  up with people and their problems.  The Doctor is out.

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay, apologies accepted!  _Everyone about turns and heads for the door, assuming he's coming with  them now._

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no... look, I-I love you all.  I really do.  But what I  want right now is to be left alone, right here, where no one  needs anything from me.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, OK.  I'll bring you some barbecue.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh my God, it's dark out here...    _The four of them exit leaving Frasier alone in the apartment in  silence.  Frasier sits down in happiness and picks up his book.  Eddie  comes in and leaps up on the sofa next to Frasier.  He lies on his  back and wriggles about._
